Buy more rental properties than you need, sell the excess, & pay off the debt on some or all of the rest.

That's one way to build financial freedom with rentals.

You'd simplify your life, increase your income, & decrease your risk.

Here's an example: 

1. Buy 20 rentals during a 5 to 10 year growth phase.
*Focus on houses & small multifamily, and work to buy at discounted prices or with value-add potential to quickly increase equity.

2. Identify your worst 10 properties, sell them

3. Pay income tax on gains (yes, I said it🫢)

4. Use cash from sales to pay off the debt on the rest (yes, I said that too😮)

Result:
You're left with 10 low maintenance rentals in your best locations.

With $2,000/mo rent per property & no debt, the after-expense income might be $1,200/mo per property.

So, the remaining 10 properties could cash flow $12,000/mo or $144,000/year.

That would pay the personal bills forever for most people.

And with well-located rentals, rent increases would also likely keep up with inflation.

And the time required, risk profile, & mental load of this portfolio is minimal.

Now do whatever you want with your time - which is the point of investing in rentals in the first place.

full_text:
It's a myth to keep a rental mortgage for the “tax benefits"

Paying off debt simply means you:

1. Reduce interest expenses
2. Make more money
3. Pay more taxes

It's not a "benefit" to make LESS money just to save on taxes.

This is business 101.

But there's more to the story:

Real estate has many tax benefits, like depreciation "expense" that shelters income from taxes.

When you pay off a mortgage, you don't lose this benefit!

The depreciation expense is still there.

It shelters the same amount of income from tax as before you paid off the debt.

You simply have more income! 

But you might argue that you'd GROW more buying more properties, not paying off 5% debt.

This is true. But it's not the same as tax benefits.

Leveraged returns on more properties will probably be much higher than 5%.

And you'll also have MULTIPLE properties which produce a lot MORE depreciation.

This extra depreciation shelters more income from tax - compounding wealth even more.

This is probably what people mean (indirectly) with the advice not to pay off debt & lose the tax benefits.

But instead of a "tax benefit" question, paying off debt is really a GROWTH vs RISK question.

Buying more properties with more debt is riskier.

As a new or growing investor, the risk is probably worth the reward.

But once you've built a lot of wealth, the risk calculus changes.

Why risk everything you've built just to get a few more properties & more "tax benefits"?

Paying off 5% debt at this later stage could be a good option.

It's in the same low-risk category as buying a treasury bond.

And it produces instant cash flow because you no longer have a mortgage payment.

Plus, paying off debt is SIMPLER and frees up more TIME than owning more rentals.

The more wealth you build, every extra dollar become less valuable than extra MINUTES and a WORRY FREE mind.

After all, isn't that the type of freedom that motivated us to invest in the first place?!

full_text:
In 2014 I began a journey to build a network of walking and biking paths in my hometown area of Clemson, SC.

I was frustrated that it was unsafe to walk a 1/2-mile to the local park with my 3-year-old daughter. And I LOVED other communities and countries where it was easy to walk and bike. 

Little did I know how hard this journey would be! 

But as an entrepreneur, I began asking "how can we fix this?!"

So, I started learning and reading books like Walkable City Rules by @JeffSpeckFAICP & @StrongTowns by @clmarohn

I talked to our @CityofClemson planning department.

I participated in community long-range planning meetings. 

I met with @ClemsonUniv professors.

It turns out I wasn't the only one who cared about this!

And one architecture professor - Dan Harding -  had been working on an idea with students called "The Green Crescent Trail." 

The vision was to build a walking and biking path to connect:
- Clemson University's core campus 
- The City of Clemson's downtown
- And the amazing 17,500 Clemson Experimental Forest encircling the community. 

But as with many good ideas, it didn't have traction OFF the university campus.

So, a group of local volunteers and I formed a non-profit in 2015 called the Friends of the Green Crescent (@GreenCrescenTr).

We held meetings.
We raised money. 
We built public awareness.
We organized people.

Our first big win was a $25k grant from Pickens County to conduct a 2016 feasibility study in two communities - Clemson and Central. 

This gave us a map, cost estimates, and a less-fuzzy big picture vision of the trail system.

But the hardest part would prove to be implementing the vision.

We didn't have 22 miles of "rails-to-trails" (@railstotrails ) like Greenville, SC with the Swamp Rabbit Trail.

So, to piece together a potential trail network we relied on voluntary easements through or along:
- private property
- city parks
- sewer easements
- churches
- and existing roads

And we had a hard time figuring out where to start with over 30+ miles of potential trails. 

So, we spun our wheels for several years with little to show for it. 

But eventually our persistence and public communication paid off.

City Council members started running on agendas that included the Green Crescent Trail. Funding followed.

Leaders at local colleges/universities began publicly supporting the trail effort, including:
-  Clemson University (@ClemsonUniv)
- Southern Wesleyan University (@SWU_edu)
- Tri-County Technical College (@tctcedu)

And very importantly, our new SC state representative Jerry Carter (@CarterSCHouse3) championed our cause and secured $1 million from the state to help us build the trail.

We also received private donations, a $50,000 sponsorship of one trail section from local hospital @AnMed_Health, and federal and state grants.

Around $4 million has been raised to date! 

This has been enough to finally build some real trails.

Later in 2023, a segment of over 3 miles connecting the City of Clemson and Clemson University will open. 

It will connect to important public spaces like:
- the SC Botanical Garden (@SCBotGarden), 
- Clemson University's campus
- City Parks
- Clemson Elementary School
- Many neighborhoods in the core of town

A few other segments are funded and in various stages of design and engineering in Central and Clemson. And we're working to connect to other nearby towns like Pendleton and Seneca. 

My 3-year old daughter is now 12 years old! And it's still not that safe to walk or bike all around town. 

But I've found a lifelong passion project in improving community walkability and bikability.  

And I've learned that you can make a difference in your community if you:
- have a strong vision
- get involved locally
- and team up with amazing people

I don't have it all figured out, but I've invested THOUSANDS of hours trying! 

So, I'm happy to discuss and answer any questions for others interested in this.

full_text:
I've roughly had three phases during my journey as a real estate investor.

Phase 1 - Beginner:
As a beginner in my early 20s, the game was to learn, make progress, and build relationships.

In those days, I flipped houses to make a living, and my wife worked as a Spanish teacher.

We used Dave Ramsey's envelope system to watch our spending. And I used low-money down strategies and house hacked my way into rental properties.

Phase 2 - Wealth Builder:
As a wealth builder in my 20's and 30s, the game was to GROW a small amount of wealth into a large amount of wealth.

I got really good at finding deals. And I mainly grew with value-add houses and small multifamily.

I scaled using private money loans, seller financing, and other creative financing strategies.

Phase 3 - Harvester:
Then things changed for me about 9 years into the journey.

I had enough wealth (millions of $) to THEORETICALLY live off of.

But it wasn't optimized.

I wasn't generating enough cash flow as a % of my wealth.

I had some dead weight properties that were maintenance nightmares and money pits.

And I had a lot of leverage and risk.

So, the new game was to harvest the wealth by:
- Turning equity into cash flow
- Pruning bad properties
- Derisking the portfolio

The primary tools were:
- Strategic refinances
- Selling certain properties
- Paying off debt
- Growing equity, but not always adding more properties (#smallandmightyinvestor)

I also did a whole lot of work on systems and team building (outsourcing).

My business partner and I self-managed properties with an internal property manager for a while. And when she retired, we outsourced to 3rd party property managers.

The Harvester Life
The work is never over, but after 5-6 years of work on harvesting wealth, the result was:
- More cash flow
- A less risky portfolio (<20% debt-to-value)
- And less time required to manage the portfolio (about 2 hours per week).

In my personal life, this coincided with taking longer sabbaticals with my family - in 2017 living 17 months in Ecuador and in 2022 living 12 months in Spain.

I also still worked, mostly writing, teaching, and volunteering with a non-profit I co-founded to build walking & biking trails in my community.

My wealth didn't grow quite as much as it could have during this final phase of selling, deleveraging, and taking time off from maximum earnings.

But in the new game, the goal was to optimize LIFE, not just returns.

And the only metric that matters to me now is how I spend my TIME.

full_text:
It's possible to find 4% interest mortgages for your long-term rental properties, even with 8% market rates.

But you won't find them in a bank or institution. 

You have to create them. 

Let me explain. 

Not long ago, I sold a retail commercial rental property for $547,000. 

When I sold, I still owed $156,000 on a seller financing mortgage that was originally $180,000.

This seller had originally financed to me because he was a little motivated.

There were issues with the existing tenant and with property repairs that needed to be solved. And he didn't want to deal with them. 

So, I agreed to buy the property for $200,000, pay $20,000 down, and take on those problems myself. 

The real sweetener for me was $180,000 of seller financing at 4% interest, fixed for 25 years with a payment of $900/mo.

Don't Pay Off the 4% Mortgage!
About 6 years after buying the property, it was stabilized and performing well with a long-term tenant.

But I'm not as comfortable with retail commercial. I prefer residential. 

So, I decided to sell it.

But I DID like the seller financing mortgage with fixed payments and 4% interest for another 19 years.

So, I decided not to pay it off.

One Profitable Little Clause
In the seller financing contract, I had negotiated a clause called a "substitution of security"

It said "Borrower may, at Borrower’s option, substitute the security for this Note to another piece (or pieces) of real property."

So, before I sold, I showed the former owner a 4-plex rental that I owned. It was worth $375,000.

He agreed to RECOLLATERALIZE  the seller financing note with a mortgage on this 4-plex. 

The Transaction Details
During the sale of the commercial property, the closing attorney satisfied the original seller financing mortgage at the county recording office. 

But the attorney did NOT pay off the seller financing note/debt.

Instead, the attorney just created a NEW mortgage for my seller and recorded it in first position against the 4-plex. 

The $156,000 I still owed the seller was now secured by a mortgage on this 4-plex  property. And I kept making him payments of $900/month like always.

Paying Off Higher Interest Debt
Before this transaction, the 4-plex had a $145,000 mortgage that I owed to a private lender at 6% interest.

I used the proceeds from the sale of the commercial property to pay that lender his money.

That allowed me to secure the $156,000 seller financing mortgage in first position mortgage. 

This was effectively a refinance of my 4-plex. 

But I sourced this refinance money from another deal by thinking ahead when negotiating seller financing. 

Today's Mantra: Borrow Low, Rent High
The key strategy in a rising interest rate market is to figure out ways to lower your financing costs.

My example can be replicated. 

You could buy properties with seller financing - likely on properties that have problems, that you may not even want to keep long-run.

You could negotiate attractive interest rates between 0% to 5%, fixed for long-terms, with a substitution of security clause.

Then you could sell the property and use the sales proceeds to pay off high interest debt or even cash-out equity on your long-term keeper properties. 

Think of it as "flip-for-financing." The financing you keep could be as valuable as the profits you make selling the original property!

Anyone else doing this or plan to do this?

I chose not to buy real estate while living in Spain for a year

I saw interesting opportunities, but I was never 100% comfortable

First, I didn't understand the market dynamics and legal environment in Spain well enough.

Specifically, I would really have to dig into and understand challenges like:
- a Spanish trend for strong squatters rights ("ocupas")
- property ownership/title as a foreigner
- historical and cultural regulations in Granada where I lived and looked at properties
- price, rent, and population trends locally

Second, successful real estate investing for me is more about the people (specifically my management team) than the real estate

I hadn't yet build a team I knew and trusted in Spain. Without a team, even a great property could be a bust.

Third, there are simpler ways to diversify, if that's my goal. 

There is an ongoing "mental drain" of paying attention to specific properties in many locations - especially international.

Fourth, I don't like to mix-up fun and investing. 

Emotionally, it might be satisfying to own something in a place I love. I could visit it repeatedly. 

But I'd rather follow @financialsamura 's mantra to "own utility and rent luxury. "

In other words, use the rent from boring properties I own in a place I understand to PAY FOR the rent and other fun, luxury experiences living in another country. 

That'll likely continue to be my strategy going forward, but I'd love to learn from others who have invested in Spain or other countries internationally.

Last week I analyzed several different investment property deals with fellow investors during 1-1 coaching calls.

In every case, the deal didn't appear to be good at first.

But the gold of good real estate deals is often found by digging below the surface.

In one case, an investor got rejected after making a seller financing offer.

I recommended that he follow-up with an offer using a 5-year lease with an option to buy at the full asking price. 

If successful, the seller would get their price and avoid management headaches.

And the investor would benefit by controlling the property's potential appreciation with little risk. 

He'd also make cash flow today  and avoid having to use bank financing at 8%+ interest rates.

Another investor was evaluating a subject-to-the mortgage deal.

Their hunch was that the numbers - as presented from a wholesaler who brought the deal - didn't work.

Our analysis confirmed their hunch.

But we evaluated what numbers WOULD work by adjusting the price down. The investor can now go back and confidently make this lower offer to the wholesaler.

Of course, the wholesaler will likely say no. But there's always a chance of a yes. 

And even if this deal doesn't work, the investor now has increased confidence on what price and terms WILL work as they continue to make offers.

Yet another investor was finding that most small multifamily deals she evaluated didn't make sense as an investment.

So, we isolated the reasons why they weren't working, and then we discussed the "levers" she could possibly change to make future deals work.

These levers included:
- Offering at a lower price
- Asking sellers/builders to buy down mortgage rates
- Negotiating seller financing
- Paying larger down payments
- Paying all cash for a property (using her own cash or a partner)
- Negotiating a subject-to-the-mortgage purchase
- Finding higher rent exit strategies (like short or mid-term rentals)

By understanding these potential levers, the investor will now adjust her buy box and search for properties with a higher likelihood of success.

In all these cases, staying at the surface-level analysis would mean NO DEAL.

But by digging into the mechanics of financing, seller negotiations, and pricing, the glittering gold of real deals starts to shine through.

That doesn't mean every deal will work. 

And you'll still have to work hard to find good deals.

But who said it was supposed to be easy?!

Not me!

I'm just saying that good deals are possible today.

And at least for me and the people I'm working with, that's exciting, hopeful, and gives us a reasonable investing plan moving forward.

In 1748 Benjamin Franklin retired early at 42 years old.

This was 20 years after starting a business from scratch in colonial America.

Yep ... Franklin started the FIRE movement (financial independence retire early) 275 years ago!

Here's how he did it:
- Learned useful skills (printing, store clerk)
- Started a business (printing) using funds from partners
- Networked and got involved in his community of Philadelphia
- Built a reputation for hard work, quality, and reliability
- Remained frugal and saved money
- Expanded his business vertically into newspapers, book publishing, and postmaster
- Expanded his business geographically into franchises and partnerships in other regions
- Reinvested much of his profits into real estate
- Set-up a partnership with his foreman to take over the business and pay Franklin half the business profits for 18 years

When he retired from his media conglomerate, Franklin’s share of the business profits were £650/yr or over $170,000/year in 2023 dollars.

But what did “retire early” really mean to Franklin?

Like today’s FIRE movement, the idea wasn’t to sit around doing nothing.

He used his abundance of time to:
- Read books
- Study interesting topics
- Make scientific experiments (remember the kite and lightning?)
- Volunteer for civic projects
- Get involved in politics
- Travel the world
- Meet interesting people

I respect Franklin’s mid-life professional pivot.

He could have grown his business, tried to “10x” his money, and been like today’s “I want to be a billionaire” trend.

But instead, he channeled his ambition, curiosity, and entrepreneurial skills beyond endlessly chasing money.

The result was Franklin:
- Made breakthrough scientific discoveries in electricity, meteorology, oceanography, and demography
- Invented the lightning rod and bifocals
- Started the first successful lending library and volunteer fire department
- Founded the University of Pennsylvania
- Helped to write the Declaration of Independence
- Gained pivotal support from France as a diplomate in the Revolutionary War
- Negotiated the Treaty of Paris to end the Revolutionary War with Britain
- Donated money and time as a philanthropist to fund initiatives like the first public hospital

And of course, his face is now on the $100 bill, aka a Benjamin!

I bought 22 properties with seller financing in my first 13 years of real estate investing

And today with 7-8% interest rates, it's more valuable than ever because you can often negotiate better rate & terms than institutional mortgages

But seller financing work a little differently than normal financing, as you can see in these diagrams.

With normal financing, a third party loans money to the buyer. 

They actually give you, the borrower, money.

With seller financing, the owner of the property agrees to wait for part of the purchase price over time (aka an installment sale). 

The seller essentially gives you CREDIT, not money. 

And that's the key difference.

The psychology of a seller, especially if they're a little motivated, is much different than a lender.

The lender is afraid to lose their money. So, they screen and underwrite you heavily as a borrower.

The ideal seller financing prospect has a problem property and likely a management headache. 

If you're trustworthy and can solve their problems, they may sell you the property and become "your bank." 

And the seller's worst case - getting the property back - just gets them back where they started. 

A lender's worst case of taking back a property is usually a problem. It's what caused the 2008-2009 financial crisis. 

That's why I find it easier to convince someone to seller finance their equity than to loan me the same amount of money. 

Of course, not every seller will finance a property. 

That's why investors should have an entire toolbox of different financing strategies. 

But if you're not out making seller financing offers today, you're missing out on a big opportunity.
name: Chad Coach Carson

full_text:
I once bought a house with seller financing ...

Sold the same house with seller financing ...

And made a profit in the process.

Here's how it worked ...

In 2005, I bought a nice brick single family house:
-  $115k = Price
-  $2k = Down Payment
- $113k = Seller financing at 5% interest

I rented the house for 4 years.

Then in 2009 (during a recession!) I sold it to my tenant with seller financing:
- $128k = Price
- $28k = Down Payment
- $100k = Seller financing at 8.232% interest

But didn't I forget something?

I still owed money on my original seller financing! 

The balance was $103,500. 

But I negotiated something important: no due on sale clause.

This allowed me to sell on owner financing in second position, but keep the underlying financing in place in first position.

So each month a third party escrow agent would:
- receive $969/mo from my tenant-buyer
- pay out $650/mo to my original seller

I got to keep the $319/mo difference

That would have been nice, but we actually decided to do something different ...

I SOLD my $100,000, 8.232% mortgage to an investor friend for $90,000  cash (a $10,000 discount).

He liked investing in mortgage notes for cash flow, and he was comfortable with the downside of a $90k note secured against a property that worth $128k.

But he didn't want the underlying, original seller financing mortgage on the property.

So, my original seller agreed to take a slight discount ($3,500) for a payoff of $100k.

Where'd I get the cash to pay it off?

$90k from new investor
$28k from tenant-buyer
=$118k of cash
-$100k payoff to original sellers
-$3k of repairs/closing costs
=$15k net cash to me

This was my first seller financing deal at 25 years old.

Looking back it was a lot of moving parts for $15k + a few years of rental cash flow

But it taught me many techniques that made me a lot of money since then, including:

- Buying with seller financing
- Lease options to tenants
- Seller financing to tenants
- Selling mortgage notes to private investors
- Negotiating NO due on sale clauses
- Wrap around financing 

When you learn to control the financing, you learn to control real estate deals and make more money

And the cool thing is those lessons are especially relevant TODAY

A Secret Business Lesson I Learned From Ebenezer Scrooge 🎄

This fall, my daughters auditioned to be in a play at a local community theater. To my surprise - my older daughter got a primary role!

She’s the ghost of Christmas past in A Christmas Carol, the classic story by Charles Dickens. My younger daughter is an extra, but she still enthusiastically strolls in the background in her Victorian-era dress! 😊

I thought I already knew the entire story, but I was surprised to pick up a secret business lesson from Ebenezer Scrooge, the lead character...

The Cold, Greedy, Old Scoundrel
Scrooge is, as Dickens describes him, “… a squeezing, wrenching, grasping, scraping, clutching, covetous old sinner!”

In short, he’s a cold, selfish, and greedy business person.

Because of this, four ghosts visit Scrooge one Christmas Eve to show him the error of his ways. And he has a personal transformation as a result.

Scrooge wakes up on Christmas a joyful, caring, and compassionate person. From that point forward, he shares love and generosity with the people around him.

Scrooge's dramatic change is a wonderful part of the story, no doubt.

But have you ever wondered how Scrooge became such a miserly, cold person in the first place?

Before Scrooge Was a Scrooge
I learned the back story of Scrooge from my daughter, the ghost of Christmas past.

In one scene, she travels back in time with Scrooge to his younger days as a 20-something apprentice. His mentor is an older business man named Mr. Fezziwig.

It's Christmas Eve, and Mr. Fezziwig insists that they put their work down, dance, and have fun at a party with his family.

At the party, Scrooge dances, laughs, and even falls in love with a beautiful young woman. He later asks this young woman to marry him.

Soon after he falls in love, Scrooge tells a friend, “One day I will make my fortune so that I will deserve her!”

And that’s what he set out to do.

Scrooge Sprints Up the Wealth Building Mountain
With his goal in mind, Scrooge dedicates himself passionately to working long hours and saving money. His combination of ambition and skill make him very successful at this aim.

But eventually, his fiancé breaks off their marriage engagement.

Why?

Because Scrooge’s passion for work and money become an obsession. He forgets the very reason he dedicated himself to work in the first place!

Said another way, Scrooge falls in love with the FUTURE, which is a fantasy.

And he forgets the PRESENT - where the person he loves actually exists.

As a result, his fiancé tearfully releases him from their engagement.

Regret - The Greatest Tragedy of All
Young Scrooge gives up love for money. For me, it was the saddest scene of the entire story.

The old Scrooge - reliving the scene next to the ghost of Christmas past (my daughter!) - just sobs to himself with regret.

Now he knows how he became the old, miserly, pitiful Scrooge.

Scrooge's Transformation is OUR Transformation
Thankfully, we learn from Scrooge.

Building wealth is wonderful. We should all work at it.

But the point isn’t the money itself.

Who cares if we’re a billionaire and have the most money possible (the topic of today’s podcast below).

The point is to live your best life!

The point is to do what matters!

If we keep THAT goal in mind, we can live life without regret in both the present AND the future.

It was his choice.

And it’s a choice we all face as wealth builders.

Then and now - Scrooge is THE example of the dark side of financial ambition left unchecked.

Cash flow & growth real estate markets both make similar TOTAL returns.

But they have different SOURCES of those returns ...

Cash flow market example:
- 7% unleveraged yield
- 2% appreciation

Growth market example:
- 3% unleveraged yield
- 6% appreciation

These differences leads to different strategies ... 

Growth markets are more tax efficient. You don't pay income tax on price growth until you sell. 

But this rewards using excess leverage.

If I buy an $800k property with $160k down, $48,000 of appreciation is a 30% return!

Pretty good idea ... until you can't pay your mortgage. 

In cash flow markets the growth strategy is about reinvesting cash flow. 

You snowball cash to buy another property or to pay off debt. 

You can build a lot of wealth in either type of market or something inbetween. 

You just have to know how to play the game.

People get an annual physical. 
So, why not rental properties? 

Recently my handyman/plumber performed annual physicals on 28 of our units

In our case, this means inspecting for existing & potential future maintenance problems (see list at bottom of post) 

He found:
- 2 water heaters leaking (need expansion tanks)
- 2 tubs leaking through to the crawl space (need caulking/sealing)
- A few rotted thresholds of backdoors (replace doors with new doors + potentially limb up trees that are causing excess shade/moisture here)
- Old exterior storage closets past their useful lives & could attract rodents (finally rip out)
- A squirrel chewing into soffit of a building (repair wood, but who knows how to deal with these pesky tree rats long run!)
- Missing a moisture barrier in one part of crawl space (install barrier) 

He's going to repair all these items for us, & I'm confident our investment now will prevent bigger costs & hassles later. 

We have great tenants, but they wouldn't have found these problems. 

And my business partner and I are pretty hands off our properties & don't visit them often. 

So, the annual physical found the problems. 

Which is why we're going to continue to do these proactive inspections annually on all of our properties.

Here's a list of things I ask him to do in the inspection:
 - Clean roof and gutters of any leaves and debris
- Inspect roof, gutters, overhangs, trim for missing, loose, or damaged shingles, leaks, or sagging or damaged gutters
- In the case of mobile homes, also for leaks in roof or windows/doors
- Inspect exterior for holes to be sealed that could allow squirrels or other pests into building
- Identify any limbs/trees that are too close to roof and needed to be trimmed
- Inspect crawl spaces for standing water or obvious moisture issues
- Inspect plumbing spigots, supply and drain lines for leaks
- Inspect decks for loose/missing railings, pickets, or steps and for any wood that's rotten or damaged and needs to be replaced
- Inspect for any wood surfaces that need restained/sealing
- Inspect driveways for large holes/damage to asphalt or cement
- Inspect exterior siding for pieces that need to be replaced
- Inspect windows for broken glass or replacement needs
- Inspect around windows and doors for any gaps/holes that need filling/caulking

Anything I'm missing on my list that you do?

full_text:
Wood & water are the maintenance weak points of my rental properties. 

So, I try to proactively deal with both to reduce hassle & increase rental cash flow. 

Let me explain ... 

Wood Problems:
- Exposed wood siding, trim, or windows - need repainting regularly
- Wood decks - need retreating or staining, but still deteriorate when exposed to sun & weather
- Wood railings? Same as decks 

Wood Solutions:
- Buy or remodel rentals with low-maintenance exteriors (brick, stone, cement board and/or metal)
- Consider selling rentals with too much exterior wood
- Keep wood decks smaller
- Use non-wood materials for windows, decking, and railings when possible. 

Water Problems: 
- Excess moisture in crawl space or basement (causes mold/fungus and rots wood structure)
- Plumbing leaks (same)
- Excess moisture inside house (same)
- Flooding (self-explanatory) 

Water Solutions:
- Buy "high lots" that sit above the grade of the road so that water naturally runs away from property. (Yes, you can install French drains, dehumidifiers, & sump pumps but they require regular upkeep & can fail)
- Install quality gutter systems that divert water away from foundation
- Avoid complex roof structures prone to leaks (my favorite rental property shape is a simple rectangle!) 
- Install thick plastic vapor barriers in crawl space
- Seal foundations with water impermeable membranes
- Proactively replace old plumbing with pex + high-quality joints and fittings (over time)
- Remind tenants to run heat/air units in summer even when gone (necessary in humid south where I invest)
- Don't buy in flood plains (duh!)

What'd I miss?

full_text:
My best $20,000 investment ...

wasn't:
- a rental property
- an index fund
- Berkshire Hathaway stock
- a car
- Bitcoin

It was a 2009 mini-retirement trip with my wife to Spain & South America when I was 29 years old.

Living in a foreign country together was our dream. 

My wife - a language teacher by trade - was itching to travel again. 

And by 2007, I was quickly burning out professionally. 

I had sprinted for 5 years flipping houses, buying rentals, & then trying to financially survive the worst recession & real estate market of a generation. 

I badly needed a break!

So, we decided to:
- save cash for over a year 
- study our travel guides (old school style!)
- pack our backpacks
- tie up loose-ends at home
- enroll in Spanish language schools
- and buy our 1-way plane tickets

During the trip, I learned to speak Spanish while living with families in Salamanca, Spain and Arequipa, Peru.

We hiked and camped on the Inca Trail to Machu Picchu, Peru and in Patagonia in Chile and Argentina. 

We met amazing new friends, saw spectacular sites, and grew closer as a couple.

But for the first 6-weeks, I had a hard time relaxing and letting go of my anxiety. 

Type-A entrepreneurial habits die hard!

Then one day in a small village on the coast near Barcelona, Spain, we spent a lazy afternoon reading & napping. 

Soon we found ourselves watching the sun set quietly over the Mediterranean Sea. 

And as the stars began to appear, a HUGE green meteor streaked across the sky.☄️

Maybe it was a sign! 

Or maybe it was the Spanish siestas and paella😴

But I felt a physical sensation like a knot untying in my chest! 

It was a sense of *relief* like I'd never felt before or sense then. 

And after, I couldn't imagine what that knot would've turned into - unchecked - for the next few decades!

That experience - and others during that 4 months - forever influenced my current approach to business, investing, & life.

I still have big ambitions.
I'm still an entrepreneur who likes to hustle.
And I haven't completely shed that anxiety. 

But a $20k investment in my 20s bought an experience that changed my perspective.

The "return" on that investment was priceless: 
- a stronger relationship with my wife
- memories 
- new friendships
- new skills
- clarity on what matters to me

And it was also the time when I began clarifying my "small and mighty" investing philosophy. 

Honestly, I could've spent 10x more & still got a deal.

When I talk to a real estate investor who has been successful for over 5 decades, I take notes!

So, here are my notes after recently interviewing John Schaub (podcast episode publishes May 13th):

Keep money relationships small and mighty: 
John's only worked with 5 or 6 private money investors/partners for over 5 decades! They liked investing with each other, so they did repeat business.

Find lazy (but experienced) money:
To keep a small group of investors, John focused on more experienced investors with more money to do more deals.

They liked real estate but wanted a more passive investment (which John could provide). 

TRUST is a competitive advantage
Having a trusting relationship with investors who have plenty of money meant John never had to worry about finding money for deals. 

As a result, John has consistently bought properties in many different economies and markets, even early on when he didn't have as much cash. 

Long-term partners ONLY:
John finds partners who have a long-term, buy-and-hold mindset like him. 

He recommends avoiding get-rich-quick types or people who have to borrow their cash.

Set reasonable investment goals:
With money partnerships, don't make promises of certain returns. 

Instead, make a simple goal - like holding until a property doubles in value. 

Then revaluate options such as:
     A. both partners sell
     B. both partners keep holding
     C. one partner buys the other out

Use simple structures that also align incentives
John uses a few basic structures with money partners and lenders:

(Structure 1) Own together as "tenants in common" (a type of legal ownership). 

The money partner invests the upfront cash and/or credit. And John provides the deal and management. 

The money partner deeds John 50% interest in the property and loans John his 50% of the partnership funds at 0% interest w/ no payments.

After that, everything is split 50:50 (profits and expenses)

(Structure 2) Use a lease option. 

Partner owns property. 

John manages using a master lease and has option to buy 50% of property at some point in the future (which would then  turn into structure 1). 

(Structure 3) Private loan from money partner.

Instead of a partnership, use a partner-lender relationship.

Pay simple interest to lender. 

Don't forget about tax benefits!:
Using simple but flexible partnership structures like these also allows you to create profitable tax strategies

For example, by owning as tenants in common - one partner can sell and use a 1031 exchange while the other can cash-out and just pay taxes. 

And by using a lease option for some partnerships, you can sell OTHER properties you own, use a 1031 exchange, and already have a property identified to buy instead of finding new ones. 

Keep it SIMPLE:
In general, keep your deals, your business, and your life as SIMPLE as possible!

For John, this means owning single family rentals in quality locations with tenants who stay for years.

John understands these deals. 
So do his money partners. 
And they all benefit in the end.

Rely More on Trust Than Contracts
Trust and alignment of interest - not fancy paperwork - make partner deals work. 

Yes, still put things in writing, but contracts aren't solutions to problems. 

The only "teeth" is litigation which makes lawyers rich (not either partner).

full_text:
You can roughly divide the world of residential rental investments into two groups:

1. Growth
2. Cash Flow

Growth investments have lower rental yields (i.e. net rent / price ratios).

Cash flow investments have higher rental yields.

But which is better?

Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger wrestled with the same question early in their investing careers.

Buffett initially bought VERY cheap businesses
And these cheap investments gave him some of his best returns EVER (on smaller amounts of capital).

He would later call these "fair businesses at GREAT prices."

They were "fair" because they often had problems with management, markets, or both.

But Buffett felt they were cheap enough that he could still make a good profit.

Cheap Rental Properties = Fair Businesses
In the real estate world, the equivalent are cheap, rundown cash flow properties.

These properties are usually older and in regions or neighborhoods with flat or even declining population growth.

Here you can get the best rent-to-price ratios (and cash flow). 

These are also the properties that can come with headaches.

But with good management, you can overcome the headaches and still make a profit.

Just be ready for a roller coaster ride of cash flow!

Charlie Munger Took Buffett to School
Buffett’s eventual business partner Charlie Munger convinced him to change gears.

Instead of buying “fair businesses at great prices” they started buying “great businesses at fair prices.”

This switch of strategy allowed them to buy some of their permanent and best investments, like:
- Geico Insurance
- Coca-Cola
- American Express
- BNSF Railroad
- and more recently a large portion of Apple

This was a lower stress, long-term, buy-and-hold strategy. 

And it allowed them to safely scale Berkshire Hathaway into the behemoth corporation that it is today.

Growth Rentals – Great Properties at Fair Prices
In real estate, the equivalent of Munger’s “great businesses at fair prices” are growth properties. 

They’re the higher quality properties in higher quality locations. They're also newer properties with fewer cap-ex issues.

I have owned both growth AND cash flow rental properties. I like them both for different reasons.

But growth properties are less intuitive to analyze
Yet many investors want to use the same metrics with growth properties as they do with cheaper, cash flow properties.

And then they get frustrated when there is no positive cash flow with small down payments (or after a  BRRRR deal). 

Or they walk away from deals because they can’t buy them at "big enough" discounts.

But like Munger and Buffett's quality businesses, I’ve learned that growth properties are also excellent investment's.

You just have to apply a different analysis lens to find “good deals.”

Growth Deal Metrics
I like to evaluate unleveraged yields on all my rentals - whether it's single family, multifamily, or commercial.

Unleveraged yield = net operating income / total cost

My quality property purchases in Clemson, South Carolina the last couple of years have been 5-6% yields. 

If we pay cash for them (which we do sometimes), we're happy with that base return. 

Or if we have private investors, they're happy with that return.

But we also expect growth.

How much? 

Typically 3% on the low end to 5% on the high end. 

Which would give us an 8% to 11% total return (without leverage).

That'll do.  Especially with lower risk. 

Negative Leverage Means Low Cash-on-Cash Yield
The days of easily buying 7% yields with 4% debt are over.

And that just means most real estate investors are buying with negative leverage.

Our debt usually costs more than our unleveraged yield. 

So, to make 7-8% financing work on these deals, down payments have to  be big

Like 40-50% big.  

And the cash-on-cash returns won't be impressive as a result.

Leverage Distorts Real Estate Analysis
But why decide to do a deal based on cash-on-cash return, anyway?

That's why we start the analysis WITHOUT leverage.

The benefit of leverage in this case just allows us to control a quality property with fixed-interest debt. 

If rents, prices, and interest rates  go up, we'll be happy even with an 8% debt.

If rents and prices stay flat but interest rates fall, we'll refinance at lower rates.

And if something else weird happens, we'll adjust and figure it out. 

That's why we keep big cash reserves and lower loan-to-value ratios.

To me, leverage makes sense when a deal is already solid. 

But when you always start with leverage, it distorts that fundamental analysis. 

The Boring Buy-and-Hold Strategy
I'm sure other people have names for it, but I’ve been calling this quality property strategy the “Boring Buy-and-Hold Strategy.”

Or the “Pretty Properties in the Path of Progress” strategy.

Patience is the primary virtue needed to win this game.

It’s not for everyone. 

Cash flow investing (or value-adds where you can do both!) still makes sense. 

But MANY real estate investors should be pursuing this approach instead of chasing cash flow yields ...

Especially those who have more money than free time and need lower hassle deals (looking at you medical professionals, lawyers, nurses, tech professionals, engineers, etc)

Getting your head around boring buy-and-hold deals requires the same mindset Warren Buffett learned from Charlie Munger.

And when you make the shift, it opens a whole different world of real estate investments!

full_text:
Last week I had a run-in with Mr. Complainy-Pants.

It started with a phone call with my real estate business partner of 21 years, Tommy.

From the start of the call I was complaining ...

"First we found termite damage in unit #4. THAT'S going to cost thousands of dollars."

"And then I noticed the entire complex looks like crap. A tree branch against the roof in one spot. Tenants left part of a pet fence in the yard. The bushes are overgrown"

"And our handyman said another unit has a tenant with a dog who's just trashed his place. Smells like urine."

"Tommy, I'm leaning towards just selling the entire property, right now."

Tommy just listened patiently.

Then he paused and said "it sounds like you're one of those motivated landlords."

😕

*guilty*

See, for years we've been buying properties from motivated landlords in this EXACT emotional state.

And just so you know, we bought those properties at LOW prices and on GREAT terms to help those landlords get rid of those same negative feelings.

So, Tommy was nicely telling me "Chad, you're in a complainy-pants downward spiral and you're not helping anything."

But being a complainy-pants felt justified because there was a lot of truth to my complaints.

Those WERE real problems!

But unfortunately, my complaining didn't help solve any of them.

Instead, it put me in a negative, non-creative mental state. And the only "logical" solution I could think of was ...

selling one of our best long-term properties.

🤦🏻

I'm sharing this, because you've probably been there, too. And if you haven't, you will!

Owning rentals will test you mentally and emotionally.

You're going to face challenges that will make you want to quit (i.e. sell).

And while selling can be the right move sometimes, it's almost never the right move when you're in the middle of a downward emotional spiral.

Even if you want to sell, solve the problems FIRST, be patient, and sell when the time is right.

By the end of my 10-minute phone conversation with Tommy, I escaped my downward spiral.

I started asking questions like:

"What's the NEXT smallest thing we can do right now to solve this problem?"

I repeated that question for my long list of complaints and created a to-do list.

Then I started DOING those next smallest things.

The problems didn't go away immediately, but my anxiety did.

And my desire to sell this property magically disappeared as fast as Mr. Complainy-Pants did.

When I was 23 years old, my mentor Dr. Louis Stone told me a simple story about how to become rich.  

Now I'm going to tell the same story to you ...  

When Louis was in his 20s working in North Carolina, he met an older, wealthy gentleman.   

One day the old man asked him: “Louis, do you want to know how to become rich?”  

Louis nodded his head enthusiastically!  
So did I when Louis asked me!  

“Ok. If you want to be rich, Louis, you need to learn to live on less than you earn.  

If you earn $40,000, live on less than $40,000.”  

“Got it, Louis?”  
“Got it!”  

“Next, you need to earn $80,000. But you need to still live on $40,000.”  

“Got it, Louis?”  
“Got it!”  

“Finally, you need to earn $120,000. But you need to still live on $40,000.”  

“Got it, Louis?”  
“Yes, got it!”  

“Louis, if you keep doing that, you can’t help but become rich. And it will happen faster than you think.”  

The point of the story: Grow your SAVINGS GAP. It's the magic of building wealth quickly and steadily.   

Yet Louis’ old mentor knew that most young people inflate their lifestyle over time.  As they earn more money, they spend more at the same time.  

This LIFESTYLE INFLATION, more than anything, destroys their chances to build wealth quickly.  

So, do you want to become rich?! 

If so, how is YOUR savings gap?  

And how can you EARN more and SPEND less to increase the gap?

Over the last 5 weeks, I've helped 38 investors find more real estate deals to buy. 

It's a new experiment we're doing in my RPM community called a "Sprint." 

A Sprint is like a short course, but the primary focus is on DOING something (not just learning). 

In 6 weeks with this "Deal Finding 101 Sprint", we're helping investors implement & improve two core ways to find deals:

1. Listed / MLS Leads
2. Professional Deal Finder Leads (agents, wholesalers, turnkey companies)

These are the basics of real estate investing ... like dribbling and shooting, blocking and tackling.

But not everyone does the basics well! 

So after 6 weeks, Sprint participants have checked milestones off their list, like:
- setting up an automated search for their Buy Box
- scheduling their daily listed lead review
- set up their lead collection & follow-up system
- set up a Scorecard (using our template) for weekly progress tracking
- reach out to 5+ professional deal finders
- set up a follow-up/nurture routine with deal finders

Sounds simple, but excellence is simple things done well. 

And in this case ... doing simple well means finding and buying more deals.

Future sprints in the works for RPM members include:
- Deal Finding 201 Sprint (Off-Market Leads) - implement direct-to-seller marketing to buy deals
- Buy Box Sprint - get clear on exactly  the ideal type of property to hunt for
- Become Bankable Sprint - get ready to pitch lenders and get preapproved 
- Rental Management Sprint - get the core leasing, rent collection, maintenance, and bookkeeping systems working well
- Deal Analysis Sprint - to get good at quickly analyzing and making offers on new deals
- Bookkeeping Sprint - get your basic bookkeeping system organized and in use

As a coach, these are my real estate versions of sports bootcamps!

Any Europeans have an opinion on this thread?

I lived in Spain for a year and in Germany briefly after college, and I agree that there seemed to be a worse culture of entrepreneurship in both places compared to the US.

In general in the US:
- It's an aspirational goal of many to have a business/side-hustle and earn a profit
- It's acceptable (& even celebrated) to fail at business & start again
- It's normal to talk about money & business without shame

But in the parts of Europe I lived in, it was the opposite. 

For example, in Spain the aspiration of many people was to be a funcionario - or someone with a secure government job. 

Becoming an entrepreneur was hard and not a typical path.
name: Chad Coach Carson

full_text:
I'll also say - there is always a tradeoff. The stability of European social support does lead to a high quality of life. 

In the US, we have people who can't get good healthcare (or it's unaffordable). 

And many people live with background anxiety about money & jobs. 

It's a nuanced comparison with pluses and minuses!

I've lost THOUSANDS of dollars with repair contractors - especially early in my real estate career.

- My first painter knocked holes in the walls with his ladder after I asked him to fix mistakes

- My first flooring contractor had seams between rooms that looked like the grand canyon!

- One of my first HVAC contractors skipped town with my $2,000 down payment for the system

- I hired a plumber who sawed through load bearing support beams to run plumbing lines (had to hire an engineer to fix🤦)

Apparently I had to learn the hard way - by losing money!

But I've also worked with amazing, win-win contractors since then. 

And I HAVE learned some lessons, like:

- Be clear and upfront with your expectations
- Inspect what you expect (often!)
- Hire from references, not ads
- Be cautious hiring the lowest bid contractor (especially if they're new to you)
- Match qualifications of the contractor to the job
- Pay your best contractors fast & generously

Any other repair contractor lessons you've learned?

full_text:
House won't rent? 
Don't automatically lower your rent price. 
Don't lower your tenant qualification standards.

Instead, I check these 4 things first:
1. The listing and photos
2. The house/apartment itself for cleanliness, other issues, neighbor problems.
3. Is it being marketing widely enough (if not, add other sites or lead sources)
4. Review customer service/response times - are we losing prospects because of not calling back, unfriendly service, not enough open houses, etc?

If I can confidently say I’ve reviewed all those and they’re good, then I’ll lower the rent price - aggressively - until I find a qualified tenant.   

An empty rent costs a lot more than lowering your rent. Sometimes you have to just swallow your pride.

And you can always raise your rent again in the future (the BIG exception being a rent control area. Different approach there).
